headline: CNN 10
subHeadline: What`s Next For TikTok Now?; Paris` Historic Notre-Dame Cathedral Reopened; Giant Butterfly Collection. Aired 4-4:10a ET

utterances.speaker: EMMANUEL MACRON, FRENCH PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: It`s a great honor for the French people to welcome you five years later and you were at that time president for thefirst time. And I remember the solidarity and your immediate reaction. So welcome back again. Merci beaucoup.

utterances.speaker: BELL
utterances.sentences: Ukraine`s President, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, was also in Paris for the reopening and took the opportunity to continue to advocate for U.S. supportin his country`s war with Russia. DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT-ELECT: It certainly seems like the world is going a little crazy right now, and we`ll be talking about that.

utterances.speaker: BELL
utterances.sentences: Trump and Macron seated together as the French president noted the symbolism in the rebuilding of this monument.MACRON (through translator): We have rediscovered what the great nations can do. We can achieve the impossible. And this cathedral is a happy metaphor for what a nation and what the world can be.

utterances.speaker: BELL
utterances.sentences: Next the organ was called back to life. Its 8,000 pipes took six months to tune, clean and reassemble. Notre Dame now restored beyond itsprevious glory and ready to hold its first mass on Sunday. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Ten-second trivia, if a butterfly`s body temperature is below 86 degrees Fahrenheit, what essential function is it unable to perform?Eating, flying, digesting or reproducing? Your answer here is flying, which explains why butterflies are always basking in the sun and angling their wings to that warm light. Now to a man who has spent a lot of time watching butterflies warm their wings. A butterfly collector in Nairobi, Kenya has dedicated so much of his life to finding, preserving and studying African butterfly species that he`s put together the world`s largest collection, over four million butterflies. He`s now looking to find a new home for the collection and a caretaker for decades of his work. CNN`s Larry Madowo shows us just how massive this collection is. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: STEVE COLLINS, BUTTERFLY COLLECTOR
utterances.sentences: There is a leaf and here are the caterpillars living underneath the leaf. We haven`t brought them in,they`ve come in of their own accord. LARRY MADOWO, CNN INTERNATIONAL CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Steve Collins has devoted his life to butterflies. His garden in Nairobi is a sanctuary for the insects.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Every day we empty these and they come in and we see, we record who`s there.MADOWO (voice-over): He traps, documents and then releases butterflies here every day.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Oh puppy, I`m going to bring this one out because it`s beautiful.

utterances.speaker: MADOWO
utterances.sentences: OK. Oh, my goodness.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: This is the white-banded emperor. There she is with her tongue feeding on my finger.MADOWO (voice-over): But it is Collins` collection of preserved butterflies which is most remarkable. (On camera): This is massive.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. It`s the biggest collection of African butterflies in the world.MADOWO (voice-over): In total, Collins has over 4 million specimens from across Africa, including 1.2 million penned in cases like these. (On camera): This is a very expensive hobby.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yeah.MADOWO (voice-over): Now in his 70s and running out of space and money to maintain the collection, he is trying to find it a new home.

utterances.speaker: MADOWO
utterances.sentences: What do you want to do with this entire collection?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Ultimately it needs to be available for scientists.

utterances.speaker: MADOWO
utterances.sentences: This is probably the world`s largest private collection of butterflies. It`s several decades worth of work across Africa. So who wouldpay for something like this? And how much would it even cost? It`s not that simple. (Voice-over): Collins is hoping a wealthy philanthropist might step in. But he has so far struggled to find a buyer, in part because he wants to keep it as a whole.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It would be a pity to break this up when it`s such an entity and it`s 30- or 40-people`s life`s work. And it needs to be tied to auniversity rather than a museum. MADOWO (voice-over): Back outside, I get a glimpse into how much work has gone into each and every one of these specimens. Yes. Nailed it.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, done.

utterances.speaker: MADOWO
utterances.sentences: I`m becoming good at this. This is a -- this is a beautiful one.EDGAR EMOJONG, STEVE COLLINS` ASSISTANT: Yes, it`s beautiful.

utterances.speaker: MADOWO
utterances.sentences: How do I hold it? Do I just?

utterances.speaker: EMOJONG
utterances.sentences: You can just hold it like this or like this.MADOWO (voice-over): Collins` assistant, Edgar Emojong, walks me through the penning process.

utterances.speaker: MADOWO
utterances.sentences: So you`re killing the butterfly right now?

utterances.speaker: EMOJONG
utterances.sentences: Yes, now. This one is dead already.

utterances.speaker: MADOWO
utterances.sentences: Oh, that was fast. It`s clearly painstaking work. So you have to be gentle not to break the wing.

utterances.speaker: EMOJONG
utterances.sentences: Yes.MADOWO (voice-over): Collins thinks his most valuable butterfly is worth $8,000. (On camera): Where is it?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I won`t show you because, you know what, of course, if somebody says, oh, that`s worth $8,000, it disappears.

utterances.speaker: MADOWO
utterances.sentences: This looks like a full-time gig.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, it`s -- it`s got out of hand. You could say it`s an obsession.MADOWO (voice-over): The future of this vast trove for scientific research hangs in the balance. Without a buyer, it could all go to waste. (END VIDEOTAPE)
